facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 5 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 5 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 7, 1959, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 470 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September, 7 1959, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 470 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellants were convicted by a Panchayati Adalat on February 5, 1950, for an offence under s. 379 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were convicted by a Panchayati Adalat on February 5, 1950, for an offence under s. 379 of the Indian Penal Code and were sentenced to a fine

facts.text: Appellants were sentenced to a fine of Rs. 751/- each by the Panchayati Adalat.

anchor.surface_text: of Rs. 751/- each. A revision against that order was taken to the High Court which was dismissed on May 13, 1953.

facts.text: Revision against the Panchayati Adalat order was dismissed by the High Court on May 13, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: A revision against that order was taken to the High Court which was dismissed on May 13, 1953. In January 1958, proceedings were taken for the recovery

facts.text: In January 1958, proceedings were taken for the recovery of the fine imposed against the appellants by the Panchayati Adalat.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1958, proceedings were taken for the recovery of the fine imposed against the appellants by the Panchayati Adalat. In a revision against that

facts.text: In revision against recovery order, objection raised that the fine was not recoverable as barred by s. 70 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: order an objection was raised that the fine was not recoverable as it was barred by s. 70 of the Indian Penal Code. The learned Sub-Divisional Magistrate

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate held by order dated February 6, 1958, that recovery of the fine is barred under s. 70 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: by his order dated February 6, 1958, held the recovery of the fine to be barred under that section. But a revision was taken to the District Magistrate

facts.text: Revision taken to District Magistrate who recommended setting aside the SDM order on ground of no period of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: But a revision was taken to the District Magistrate who recommended the setting aside of the order of the sub-Divisional Magistrate on the ground that

facts.text: High Court by order dated September 7, 1959 accepted recommendation of District Magistrate and held no limit for realizing fines by Panchayati Adalat.

anchor.surface_text: there was no period of limitation. The High Court by its order dated September 7, 1959 accepted the recommendation of the District Magistrate and held

facts.text: Appellants brought this appeal by special leave against the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: that there is no limit to the time within which the fines imposed by a Panchayati Adalat can be realised. It is against this order that the appellants

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that District Magistrate and High Court erred in holding s.70 IPC inapplicable to fines by Panchayati Adalats.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the District Magistrate as well as the High Court were in error in holding that the period of limitation provided by s. 70 of the Indian

facts.text: Limitation under s.70 IPC starts from date of conviction by Panchayati Adalat, not from dismissal of revision by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the limitation started from the date of conviction by the Panchayati Adalat and not from the date of dismissal of Revision by the

facts.text: Offence under s.379 IPC is cognizable by Panchayati Adalats under s.52 of U.P. Panchayat Raj Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 52 of the Act, certain offences are cognizable by the Panchayati Adalats and the offence under s. 379 of the Indian Penal Code is one of them.

facts.text: Panchayati Adalats have no power to inflict substantive sentences of imprisonment under s.54 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 54 empowers these Panchayati Adalats to impose penalties and it is provided that they have no power to inflict substantive sentences of

facts.text: Provisions of CrPC, Evidence Act, Limitation Act inapplicable to Panchayati Adalats except as per the Act, under s.83.

facts.text: No provision in U.P. Panchayat Raj Rules for period of limitation for fines by Panchayati Adalats.

holdings.text: In our opinion the District Magistrate as well as the High Court were in error in holding that the period of limitation provided by s. 70 of the Indian Penal Code is inapplicable to the recovery of fines imposed by Panchayati Adalats.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the District Magistrate as well as the High Court were in error in holding that the period of limitation provided by s. 70 of the Indian Penal Code is inapplicable to the recovery of fines imposed by Panchayati Adalats.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act does not exclude s.70 IPC; s.83 inapplicable to IPC; s.94 supports by allowing SDM recovery as own fine, implying same limitation applies.

holdings.text: But the language of s. 70 prescribes the terminus quo to be the date of passing of the sentence by Court which passes such order and the filing of appeal or revision does not, unless specifically ordered, arrest the operation of the order of passing of the sentence of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: But the language of s. 70 prescribes the terminus quo to be the date of passing of the sentence by Court which passes such order and the filing of appeal or revision does not, unless specifically ordered, arrest the operation of

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.70 refers to sentence by convicting court; revision or appeal does not suspend sentence unless expressly ordered.

holdings.text: In the present case the limitation started from the date of conviction by the Panchayati Adalat and not from the date of dismissal of Revision by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the limitation started from the date of conviction by the Panchayati Adalat and not from the date of dismissal of Revision by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies textual meaning of s.70 to facts: limitation from Panchayati Adalat conviction date (1950), rendering 1958 recovery time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the District Magistrate as well as the High Court were in error in holding that the period of limitation provided by s. 70 of the Indian Penal Code is inapplicable to the recovery of fines imposed by Panchayati Adalats.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order set aside; period of limitation under s.70 IPC applicable to recovery of fines imposed by Panchayati Adalats; limitation runs from date of Panchayati Adalat conviction
